text:
This is a open forum,
and we're going

to talk about the open letter
to cause giant AI experiments.

And it was published-- it came
out of a organization, which

feels that we need to be
very cautious about AI and this is from my
point of view a way

of figuring out what people
are thinking about this.

In any case I'm not
going to provide a great deal of
early structure here,

but if someone has
an opinion, they're willing to open up the
conversation, that would be it.

I would suggest you unmute
your microphone before talking.

I've been reading Bruce
Schneier's newsletter, and he had two different
articles on the risks here.

This of this kind of thing-- He did not sign the
open letter, by the way.

I didn't know that,
but as I gather, his main point is the risk
is that these things will

be trained to manipulate the
way people see certain events. That was one of the articles.

The other one was on how it
makes lobbying easier at scale.

He pointed out the
things that lobbyists do and how time consuming that
is, and how these tools can do

the bulk of that work at scale. I mean, do thousands
instead of one

at a time to
influence legislators. So that's my knowledge
of the subject,

and those seem like real risks. Well, they may be real risk,
but don't we do that already?

Well, we have lobbyists, but it
might take two lobbyists a month

or more to influence a
legislator in some way, and these tools can influence
100 legislators in a day.

That's what he
meant by at scale.

The difference is the scale. Isn't that the beauty of having
a system though, one which

is automated and is efficient? And this isn't no different than
anything that we do currently,

it's just more efficient having
a car to go across the country.

Right. But there are things that
we are happy to see be inefficient like retail theft.
that may not be a--

that may not be a problem. There are communities
where theft

may be perfectly acceptable. Well, my point is that there
are things that we currently

put up with because they're
at a manageable scale. So we put up with lobbying.

In fact, lobbying
has great value, but we put up with it because
it's at a manageable scale.

But what if the influence
was 100 times more efficient,

that might not be something
that we would want to see.

That's the point he's making. These things never
occurred to me.

Well, I mean, you're a
technologist and things that some of these
non-technologist people--

Bruce is a technologist,
by the way.  I don't know.

Yeah, and then the other one is
today most of the misinformation

is not tightly targeted
to individuals, whereas at the
scale of these AI,

they can-- when they're giving
me a response to a question, they can know a lot about me
and target the response to me

individually, and do that with
every one of millions of people who are trying to learn
about a given issue,
and that's another risk.

And that's a reason
for not allowing it to be developed further.

Well, my understanding of the
letter which I didn't read

was that we have
these risks and we don't know what to do about
them, so let's slow down--

let's not put out the-- make
the next generation available until we have a handle on
how to deal with the risks.

That's my understanding of
the intent of the letter. That's the understanding
of the intent letter.

Did you look at the-- looking at the
list of signatures

is definitely worthwhile. And I have a fairly
broad knowledge base

of who's doing what, where. And the vast majority
of the 1,000 experts

are retired emeritus
professors and professors of some liberal arts field
or something like that.

They're not experts in
artificial intelligence. There are people who
were quite credible,

but they were actually
fairly few and far between in the population
that signed the letter.

Yeah, I've been asked to
sign these letters too where I have no particular
expertise, and I simply said no,

but a lot of people
would just sign on because it's like people
who sign petitions I guess.

Without thinking deeply,
it sounds reasonable so they sign on.

But there are some very
serious thinkers on that list, and so it's worth thinking
about, worth this discussion.

There were serious thinkers on
that list, very few of them. It doesn't take a lot.

Five out of-- I don't

but if five serious thinkers

think this is a problem,
they're worth listening to. Well, at the risk of causing
a bit of a schism here,

you believe that Elon is a

I don't think he's a serious

he's been warning about

I'm not really sure that I-- I think that most of

Yeah, that's true, but we

I would have said, wait, but
let's not take that chance. That penalty is quite high.

Well, yeah but again,
you have to really-- when you evaluate
positions people have,

you have to evaluate

were a little crazy. I don't think they were crazy.

So I think they'll still

will the transition look like?

You think that there's
still a need for people.

Yeah, I think
you're right there. First of all, the thing that no

they're extremely friendly.

out of whole cloth.

And whether they're true or

will probably get fixed.

Well, there's two
problems that I see. When it first came out, I was
concerned about my son's job.

Yeah. Well, but the point is that

announcement of the game,

it treats that as correct. Even though there's been
a correction added later,

it wouldn't have a way to know. So now that-- is that
fixable without having

some broader context to
evaluate quality of information?

The answer I think is yes. Actually, fairly easily. But that's a slight modification
of the training mechanism.

I don't know how

And I'm asking

So let somebody else talk. Yeah. I'm good.

I've said everything I
know and some that I don't.

Right time to take
off with the beginning session of the quarter.

Get one person on one--
well, you're on one side

I'm in favor of slowing

the research can go on, but

Not that they shouldn't

we saw some really bad stuff
with the first being one.

before I put a special weight

Well, I have a different view.

I think that trying to control

Because the copyright

Even if they're human authors. Well, the American

So that may not be

What's a work of authorship? And what's derivative works?

Because the way in which

is they decompose

with a position in the universe

as a derivative work in

based upon knowledge

which is gained by the computer
program observing other data.

It changed the

The more things, the more

That is correct.

And the other thing is
